articles.headline: U.S. Reaches Deal With Iran to Free Americans for Jailed Iranians and Funds
articles.snippet: Five American detainees will eventually be allowed to leave Iran in exchange for Tehran gaining access to $6 billion for humanitarian purposes and the United States freeing several jailed Iranians.
articles.abstract: Five American detainees will eventually be allowed to leave Iran in exchange for Tehran gaining access to $6 billion for humanitarian purposes and the United States freeing several jailed Iranians.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States and Iran have reached an agreement to win the freedom of five imprisoned Americans in exchange for several jailed Iranians and eventual access to about $6 billion in Iranian oil revenue, according to several people familiar with the deal.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Supreme Court Pauses Opioid Settlement With Sacklers Pending Review
articles.snippet: A federal appeals court had signed off on the agreement, which would shield members of the wealthy Sackler family from opioid-related lawsuits in exchange for billions to resolve thousands of claims.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals court had signed off on the agreement, which would shield members of the wealthy Sackler family from opioid-related lawsuits in exchange for billions to resolve thousands of claims.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday temporarily blocked a bankruptcy deal for Purdue Pharma that would have shielded members of the billionaire Sackler family, which once controlled the company, from additional civil lawsuits over the opioid epidemic and that capped the Sacklers’ personal liability at $6 billion.
articles.byline: By Abbie VanSickle and Jan Hoffman

articles.headline: Death Toll Soars in Maui, as Rescue Crews Scour Decimated Town
articles.snippet: Lahaina lay in ruins following a wildfire that the governor said most likely killed more than 60 people, making it the deadliest in Hawaii’s history.
articles.abstract: Lahaina lay in ruins following a wildfire that the governor said most likely killed more than 60 people, making it the deadliest in Hawaii’s history.
articles.lead_paragraph: The death toll in a historic Maui town leveled by a wildfire soared to 53 on Thursday as the U.S. military joined search and rescue operations in the charred ruins of one of Hawaii’s most celebrated tourist destinations.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Spiraling Legal Bills Threaten Trump With a Cash Crunch
articles.snippet: The former president’s political orbit, including the super PAC that backs him, is already spending more than it is taking in — an unusual trajectory this far out from an election.
articles.abstract: The former president’s political orbit, including the super PAC that backs him, is already spending more than it is taking in — an unusual trajectory this far out from an election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s legal problems aren’t just piling up — his legal bills are, too.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: She Once Ran Against Putin. Her Advice Now: Resistance Is Futile
articles.snippet: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best known media figures still in Russia, says her fatalistic stance just reflects a grim reality. Some liberals call her a Kremlin stooge, while hawks see her as disloyal.
articles.abstract: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best known media figures still in Russia, says her fatalistic stance just reflects a grim reality. Some liberals call her a Kremlin stooge, while hawks see her as disloyal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emerging from a friend’s Maserati on southern Spain’s Mediterranean coast, Ksenia Sobchak wants the world to know: Back home in Russia, fighting for change is futile.

articles.headline: Goldman’s C.E.O. Is Stuck, Without a Clear Lifeline
articles.snippet: David Solomon’s management style is winning few fans amid the elite investment bank’s performance woes. He is mired in “quicksand” and unsure what to do.
articles.abstract: David Solomon’s management style is winning few fans amid the elite investment bank’s performance woes. He is mired in “quicksand” and unsure what to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day in mid-June, Lloyd Blankfein called David Solomon, chief executive of Goldman Sachs. Mr. Solomon had not been expecting it.

articles.headline: Make the Whole Place Shimmer: America Spends Big for Beyoncé and Taylor Swift
articles.snippet: The artists’ fans have been shelling out on lavish wardrobes, parties and travel, generating business and boosting spending in host cities.
articles.abstract: The artists’ fans have been shelling out on lavish wardrobes, parties and travel, generating business and boosting spending in host cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beyoncé told us that girls run the world. This summer, she and Taylor Swift seemed to prove it.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Jordyn Holman, DeSean McClinton-Holland and Maggie Shannon

articles.headline: China’s Stalling Economy Puts the World on Notice
articles.snippet: As China’s economy flashes indications of decline, the consequences pose perils for countries around the globe.
articles.abstract: As China’s economy flashes indications of decline, the consequences pose perils for countries around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a quarter-century, China has been synonymous with relentless development and upward mobility. As its 1.4 billion people gained an appetite for the wares of the world — Hollywood movies, South Korean electronics, iron ore mined in Australia — the global economy was propelled by a seemingly inexhaustible engine.

articles.headline: Yellow Says It Will Repay Federal Debt. Legal Experts Are Skeptical.
articles.snippet: The trucking company, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, owes more than $700 million to the Treasury Department.
articles.abstract: The trucking company, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, owes more than $700 million to the Treasury Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yellow, a trucking company that filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday, told a judge this week that it would fully repay the $729 million it owed the federal government by selling warehouses, trucks and other assets. But with its industry in a downturn, Yellow could struggle to get top dollar for its assets.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Madeleine Ngo
